resources.string:
DSO Planner is astronomy observations planning software, targeting experienced deep sky objects' visual observers.

Developers: Leonid Vasiliev, Alexandre Koukarine

German translation, thanks to: Felix Ittner, Jens Imohr

Ukrainian translation, thanks to: Leonid Tkachuk
With all inquiries please e-mail to dsoplanner@gmail.com, visit the application website www.dsoplanner.com or user support forum
With all inquiries please e-mail to dsoplanner@gmail.com, visit the application website www.dsoplanner.com or user support forum

SQL string (in any register):
TYPE - object type. TYPE could be equal to GC, GX, GCYCLD, HIIRGN, NEB, OC, OCNEB, PN, SNR, MPLANET, STAR, DS, COMET, CUSTOM, CG, DN, AST, NF, QS.
A - the first object dimension.
B - the second object dimension.
RA, DEC - object coordinates.
MAG - magnitude.
PA - position angle.
CON - constellation.

Local string:
ALT - altitude.
VIS - visibility.

Shortcuts tip:
c73 - for Caldwell 73
mars - planet name
h5056 - Yale Bright Star Catalog
(1) ceres, (1), ceres - for minor planet (1) Ceres

The DSO objects' images used in the DSO Planner are from the Digitized Sky Survey as used by The NGC/IC Project LLC - Please see www.ngcicproject.org for copyright information.

The Digitized Sky Surveys were produced at the Space Telescope Science Institute under U.S. Government grant NAG W-2166. The images of these surveys are based on photographic data obtained using the Oschin Schmidt Telescope on Palomar Mountain and the UK Schmidt Telescope. The plates were processed into the present compressed digital form with the permission of these institutions.

 The National Geographic Society - Palomar Observatory Sky Atlas (POSS-I) was made by the California Institute of Technology with grants from the National Geographic Society.

 The Second Palomar Observatory Sky Survey (POSS-II) was made by the California Institute of Technology with funds from the National Science Foundation, the National Geographic Society, the Sloan Foundation, the Samuel Oschin Foundation, and the Eastman Kodak Corporation.

 The Oschin Schmidt Telescope is operated by the California Institute of Technology and Palomar Observatory.

 The UK Schmidt Telescope was operated by the Royal Observatory Edinburgh, with funding from the UK Science and Engineering Research Council (later the UK Particle Physics and Astronomy Research Council), until 1988 June, and thereafter by the Anglo-Australian Observatory. The blue plates of the southern Sky Atlas and its Equatorial Extension (together known as the SERC-J), as well as the Equatorial Red (ER), and the Second Epoch [red] Survey (SES) were all taken with the UK Schmidt.
This image is used with permission of\nThe NGC/IC Project LLC (www.ngcicproject.org)

Settings circles one star alignment brief instruction:\nPoint your telescope at the object, selected on the chart, and hit Now button. Check your setting circles and enter the Azimuth and Altitude readings into provided fields. Hit One Star Align button to capture the adjustment values. Use Settings menu to toggle display of adjusted Az/Alt values instead of actual ones.

- b (minor axis size)

- pa (position angle)

Manage search requests for object selection

Quick Start Guide
The application supports two approaches to object selection. The easier way is to turn on the Star Chart object layers (NgcIc, PGC) and set limiting magnitude for each layer and field of view (FOV). All objects whose magnitude is below limiting will then be shown on "Star Chart". Besides limiting magnitude you could also filter NgcIc layer by object types.

The second approach is to look through several databases for objects to be observed using various filters ("Object Selection"), prepare observation list and get its objects on "Star Chart" automatically.

You could use each approach separately or combine them. For separate use turn off object layers and fill the current observation list, or vice versa turn on object layers and clear current observation list. For combination both turn on object layers and fill the current observation list.

Star Chart
"Star Chart" shows stars and objects from the selected layers and ALL objects from the current observation list. For each FOV and layer you could adjust limiting magnitude to raise/diminish the number of stars/objects that you see on the screen.

Star Chart is highly customisable, there are many options in "Star Chart Settings" that help you adjust it to your needs.

By default, "Star Chart" depicts preinstalled Digitized Sky Survey (DSS) images and their contours. They are not objects in a usual sense, rather consider them belonging to DSS image layer. To download DSS image of any object/sky portion select an object or a star and go to Menu/DSS. Remove DSS image or download image of adjacent area with two long touches on existing image/adjacent area.

Object Selection
To search for objects go to "Object Selection" screen. Press "Select" button. Select object types, catalogs, minimum dimension, visibility filter (object visibility, maximum magnitude) and minimum altitude.

Return back. Select your geographic location, observation time range and sky conditions. Return back and press "Update" button. Here you are with a list of objects.

Press on the object to see its location on "Star Chart". Long tap on the list and select "Add (all) to observation list" to add object(s) to the current observation list (and they become visible on Star Chart).

Observations Lists

There are four observation lists. The current one is displayed in "Observations Lists" screen, its objects are shown on "Star Chart". Change the current observation list in Menu. Menu provides for other observation list operations (sorting, note matching, etc.) as well.

Manual
dsoplanner.com/files/DSO_Planner_User_Manual.pdf

This update includes:

+ new object layers (NgcIc, UGC) for Star Chart
+ adjustable star and object magnitude limits for each FOV
+ 3 compass modes, compass fine settings
+ star chart settings rearranged
+ user horizon from text file
+ equatorial grid and grid labels
+ labels for dso and bright stars
+ famous nebula contours now drawn for each FOV
+ option to fill area below (user) horizon
+ details screen rearranged
- bug fixes

This update includes:

+ DSO Selection list could be sorted by pressing at column title
+ choosing database in DSO Selection is moved under Select button
+ Basic Search in DSO Selection adjusts search criteria to database chosen
+ Stop button is added to DSO Selection search
+ Move option is added to Observation Lists (to change order of objects)
+ real time mode settings are reorganised
+ new real time mode option is added (no screen update for high zoom levels)
+ selected object magnitude in Star Chart is shown at the bottom left corner
+ eyepieces FOV is shown for all FOV if not too small
+ Planet is renamed to mPlanet for minor planets
- bug fixes

This update includes:

+New editions (Basic and Plus) available! Consider them if you like the app

+ DSO Selection list could be sorted by pressing at column title
+ choosing database in DSO Selection is moved under Select button
+ Basic Search in DSO Selection adjusts search criteria to database chosen
+ Stop button is added to DSO Selection search
+ Move option is added to Observation Lists (to change order of objects)
+ real time mode settings are reorganised
+ new real time mode option is added (no screen update for high zoom levels)
+ selected object magnitude in Star Chart is shown at the bottom left corner
+ eyepieces FOV is shown for all FOV if not too small
+ Planet is renamed to mPlanet for minor planets
- bug fixes

"

"
DSO Planner supports Google Auto Backup - the app preferences and user data (except for user object databases, dss images, voice notes, exported data) are automatically backed up by your phone and restored when you install / reinstall the app.
Besides DSO Planner supports its own full backup / restore. DSO Planner is keeping the following user data on the internal phone storage: * User databases. * Observation lists. * App preferences. * DSS images. * Audio notes. * Import / export text files.
With the help of Android system file picker: * \"Backup\" command copies files from the internal phone storage to external folder named \"backup\". * \"Restore\" command copies files from external folder named \"backup\" back to the internal phone storage.
After executing \"Backup\" command the \"backup\" folder will contain the following subfolders: * databases * dss * notes * images
To backup all your data off the phone: 1. Call \"Backup\" command. 2. Connect it to your computer with USB cable, use OTG device, or open network/cloud folder from the phone. 3. Manually copy \"backup\" folder from the phone to your remote folder.
To restore your data back to the phone: 1. Call \"Restore\" command and choose the folder named \"backup\"
Would you like to help localizing (translating) the app to your language? Send an email to devs!\nAlready supported: Russian, German, Ukrainian
